title: Current risk
text:
Wildfire Exposure Risk
Using methods of Dr. Jennifer Beverly (see https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007/s10980-020-01173-8.pdf) and fire hazard assignments from Robert (‘Zeke’) Zeil we generated this draft map.



Draft Wildfire Exposure Risk.

title: Historical Fire Regimes
text: INCOMPLETE DRAFT FOR INTERNAL CONSUMPTION ONLY

title: Historical Fire Regimes
text:
Summary
Historically the Northwoods experienced, on average, ~1.2M acres of fire annually. These fires were largely ignited as part of Indigenous land management practices (see Stewart, 2002). Areas with relatively short historical MFRIs were spread across the region with several areas standing out including:

central Minnesota
northeastern and northwestern Wisconsin
large sections of the northern half of the lower peninsula of MI

While these large areas stand out, there are historically fire adapted ecosystems peppered across much of the region. Notably, some of the fire-adapted ecosystems were surrounded by ecosystems with typically long MFRIs, such as northern hardwoods limiting spread. Further, most of the ecosystems with short MFRI were dominated by surface fires that would have killed less than 25% of the vegetation.



Most historical fires occurred in pine, oak and peatland dominated ecosystems, especially the barrens types.

title: Northwoods Fire Assessment
text:
INCOMPLETE DRAFT FOR INTERNAL CONSUMPTION ONLY

Why this why now: Evaluating the potential for transformational changes in ecosystem condition and wildfire risk for the Northwoods region
Wildfires, drought, ice and windstorm events, and other natural disturbances are foundational processes that shape the condition of ecosystems, and the services they provide to people. Anthropogenic drivers like introduced pests and pathogens, groundwater depletion, and fire suppression can disrupt natural processes, and reduce the resilience of forest ecosystems to disturbances.



Northwods Fire Assessment Boundary. Compiled by Randy Swaty from Bailey’s Ecoregions (Bailey, 2016. https://doi.org/10.2737/RDS-2016-0003)


Further, we expect that climate change, especially temperature-related increases in evaporative demand (a key indicator of water loss rates from soils and vegetation), has the potential to rapidly amplify the effects of anthropogenic stressors, promoting drought stress in forest vegetation, and transformational increases in fire risk.
While these risks to forests of the Northwoods Region are pervasive and associated with many uncertainties, understanding the spatial patterns of past disturbances, current vegetation conditions, management and water use history, and site conditions can help us compare relative risks for catastrophic fires.

title: Recent fires
text: INCOMPLETE DRAFT FOR INTERNAL CONSUMPTION ONLY

title: Recent fires
text:
Summary
In the period between 1992 and 2020 over 74,000 fires were recorded for the Northwoods region (data from Short 2022). While most of these were immediately suppressed, this number is substantial. Below we explore:

fire count and size trends
seasonality
location

title: Recent fires
text:
Fire Count and Monthly Trends
The mean number of fires per year in the Northwoods is ~2550, with a range of 1,220 - 4,242 per year.










The mean number of fires over the 28 year time period ranged from 6 - 1,0222, with the highest number of fires occurring in April.










Pulling it altogether in the following ridgeline chart allows for exploration across months for the entire time period. The highest peaks represent 217 fires (which occurred July 14, 2005)

title: Recent fires
text:
Fire size distribution
Roughly 70,000 of the reported fires were less than 10 acres, and ~600 fires were greater than 100 acres.

title: Recent fires
text:
Spatial Distribution of Fires
For the map below I clipped the Short (2022) fire occurrence data to the Northwoods perimeter with a buffer of 10km, as this data was coupled with perimeter data for exploration as some fires extended outside of the Northwoods area. The dataset has a cause attribute which was used to categorize ‘natural’ vs. ‘human’ causes.



Fire occurances within the Northwods fire assessment boundary (plus 10km buffer) for 1992 - 2020.
